channel.title: JavaScript Weekly
channel.description: A newsletter of JavaScript articles, news and cool projects

item.title: ã€The JavaScript trademark fight rumbles onã€‘JavaScriptå•†æ ‡åµæ¶
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹730 â€” April 4, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Bare: A New Lightweight Runtime for Modular JS Apps â€” Imagine something like Node.js but really stripped back: bare, if you will. Like Node, itâ€™s built on top of V8 and libuv (though it's designed to support multiple JavaScript engines) but Bareâ€™s approach is to provide as little as possible (a module system, addon system, and thread support) and then rely upon userland modules that can evolve independently of Bare itself. Itâ€™s an interesting idea â€“ more detailsÂ here.

Holepunch

An Update on the Deno v Oracle JavaScriptâ„¢ Fight â€” Deno filed a petition with the USPTO to cancel the 'JavaScript' trademark, as claimed by Oracle, and Oracle stepped up to fight back. Ryan recaps the basic story and asks for help to get the word out (signing the open letter is a great start, if you agree Oracle abandoned theÂ trademark).

Ryan Dahl

AG Grid: The Best JavaScript Data Grid In The World â€” Create high-performance data grids with our open-source library, trusted by 90% of the Fortune 500. Add advanced features like Integrated Charting, Grouping, Pivoting and more with a few lines of code. Supports React, Angular and Vue. TryÂ forÂ free.

AG Grid sponsor

React 19.1 Released â€” The headline feature is Owner Stacks, a dev-only feature to track which components are responsible for rendering otherÂ components. 19.1 also brings fixes, small additions (like support for streaming in edge environments), a new API for prerendering RSCs on the server, and enhanced Suspense support.

Matt Carroll (Facebook)

IN BRIEF:

  • Safari 18.4 has been released with Declarative Web Push support, iterator helpers, Error.isError, and faster JSON.parse and JSON.stringifyÂ functions.

  • There's a longstanding proposal to bring TS-style enums to JavaScript and author Ron Buckton will be pitching it to TC39 at its next meeting. Here's a slidedeck covering the benefits. Thanks to Rob Palmer for highlightingÂ this.

  • The ES2025 spec has reached candidate stage in anticipation of being finally approved inÂ June.

RELEASES:

  • Express 5.1 â€“ The long standing Node.js web framework gets a bump with 5.x finally becoming the latest tagged version onÂ npm.

  • React Email 4.0 â€“ Components and tools for rendering HTML emails.

  • zx 8.5 â€“ Google's tool for better Node shellÂ scripting.

  • Astro 5.6, Ember 6.3, Turborepo 2.5, Node.js v23.11.0, Bun v1.2.8

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Exploring Art with TypeScript, Jupyter, Polars, and ObservableÂ Plot â€” One of Denoâ€™s compelling features is its support for Jupyter Notebooks and easy notebook-style programming, such as is common in the Python world. Trevor looks at a practical use of using such a notebook environment for dataÂ exploration.

Trevor Manz

Could JavaScript Have Synchronous await? â€” Dr. Axel reflects on the problems around async code being different to synchronous code and ways around the limitations faced. What could the consequences of a synchronous await be?

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

Hands-On Debugging Session: Instrument, Monitor, and Fix â€” Build it, break it, debug it, and fix it â€” with Sentry. See how to get set up, track errors, use Session Replay and the new Trace Explorer, plus leverage AI to find and fix issuesÂ fast.

Sentry sponsor

JavaScript's Missing Link? Wasp Offers a Full Stack Solution â€” A look at what the Wasp team is trying to do building a full-stack webapp framework around React, Node, and Prisma. Itâ€™s a powerful option if youâ€™re looking for a more traditional-feeling full-stackÂ approach.

Loraine Lawson (The New Stack)

ğŸš‚ How a Steam Locomotive from 1993 Broke My Yarn Test â€“ A fun bug hunting tale that actually delivers on itsÂ title. Yew Leong

ğŸ“„ Breaking Down Circular Dependencies in JavaScript Bryan Braun

ğŸ“„ Automated Visual Regression Testing with Playwright Frederik Dohr

ğŸ“„ Lessons Learned From My First Dive Into WebAssembly Chris Wellons

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Anime.js 4.0: A JS Animation Library for the Web â€” If youâ€™re tired of Web animations, maybe Anime.js will refresh your appetite. This is a major upgrade to a mature library for animating CSS properties, SVGs, the DOM, and JS objects. Itâ€™s smooth, well-built, and now complete with freshÂ documentation.

Julian Garner

Learn How to Integrate Clerk with Lovable â€” Lovable integrates Clerk for custom domains, streamlined auth flows, and waitlist-poweredÂ onboarding.

Clerk sponsor

Milkdown 7.7: WYSIWYG Markdown Editor Framework â€” A WYSIWYG Markdown editor framework based around a plugin system that enables a high level of customization. The docs are rendered by Milkdown itself. GitHubÂ repo.

Mirone

TinyBase v6.0: A Reactive Data Store for Local-First Apps â€” Weâ€™re huge fans of this powerful reactive data store that can be used as the entire backend for many types of app. v6.0 adds no new functionality but brings React 19 support and goes ESM-only. Check out the homepage forÂ more.

James Pearce

  • ğŸ¤– node-llama-cpp 3.7 â€“ Run LLMs locally with bindings toÂ llama.cpp.

  • bignumber.js 9.2 â€“ Arbitrary-precision decimal and non-decimal arithmetic.

  • TS-Pattern 5.7 â€“ Pattern matching library with smart typeÂ inference.

  • React Admin 5.7 â€“ Framework for building B2B frontendÂ interfaces.

  • UVCanvas 0.3 â€“ Render beautifully shaded canvases fromÂ React.

  • Danfo.js 1.2 â€“ Pandas-inspired JavaScript data analysis toolkit.

  • Vuetify 3.8 â€“ Vue componentÂ framework.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

âœ‰ï¸ Don't forget we have two other JavaScript related newsletters if you work with Node.js or React: Node Weekly and React Status respectively.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere

A quick roundup of other interesting updates and useful resources from across the broader developerÂ landscape:

  • If you fancy writing a blog post that could make it into JavaScript Weekly, checking out How to Write Blog Posts that Developers Read by Michael Lynch isn't a bad idea..Â :-) (Then hit reply and tell us aboutÂ it!)

  • Chrome 135+ includes support for the CSS Overflow 5 spec which makes it easier to create native scrolling and carousel experiences.

  • Yoni Goldberg writes about the sweet and powerful 'use case' codeÂ pattern.

  • Some tips from GitHub for project maintainers: 5 GitHub Actions Every Maintainer Needs to Know

  • ğŸ¤– The New Stack's Alex Williams looks at how AI agents are transforming frontend development.

item.title: ã€Comparing Tauri and Electronã€‘æ¯”è¾ƒé™¶é‡Œå’Œç”µå­
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹731 â€” April 11, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

ğŸ¤–Â Firebase Studio: Google's New Agentic AI-Powered Development Environment â€” Buzzing from the success of Gemini 2.5 Pro for dev tasks, Googleâ€™s Firebase team gets in on the AI development action with a Cursor/v0/Lovable-a-like of its own for building apps in theÂ browser.

Google

Some Features Every JavaScript Developer Should Know in 2025 â€” A quick list post breezing through a few more modern areas of JavaScript including iterator helpers, structuredClone(), and setÂ operations.

Suren Enfiajyan

Next.js Fundamentals, v4 â€” Master Next.js with Scott Moss. Learn React Server Components, Server Actions, dynamic routing, authentication, caching, and edge functions. Create a modern React app, deploy it to Vercel, and level up yourÂ skills.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Node.js Testing Best Practices â€” A detailed guide to modern testing in Node from a group of developers who know all about it. Itâ€™s on GitHub, but essentially written like a free book covering over 50 battle-tested tips covering areas as diverse as the â€˜Testing Diamondâ€™, testing microservices, and simulating flakyÂ networks.

Goldberg, Salomon, and Gluskin

IN BRIEF:

  • There's speculation that the npm registry may have wiped all access tokens. If you're having problems, the status update recommends creating new tokens while they attempt to restoreÂ them.

  • â˜ï¸ It's been a busy week for Cloudflare! It now has an easy way to deploy Next.js apps to Cloudflare Workers, you can add a 'deploy to Workers' button to your Git repos, v1 of their Cloudflare Vite plugin has been released, and you can now deploy an entire frontend, backend, and database (supporting React Router, Astro, Vue.js, Svelte and more) in oneÂ Worker.

  • The RedwoodJS team has an update on the future of Redwood and what the 'next epoch' holds for the React-basedÂ framework.

  • p5.js 2.0 looks like it'll be with us soon â€“ its eighth beta has just landed. The release notes for beta 2 give an extensive idea of what'sÂ coming.

  • ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡´ The annual JSHeroes conference is taking place this May 29-30 in Cluj,Â Romania.

RELEASES:

  • TypeSpec 1.0-RC â€“ Microsoft's language for defining cloud service APIs andÂ shapes.

  • pnpm 10.8 â€“ The alternative, efficient packageÂ manager.

  • Prisma 6.6 â€“ Popular ORM for Node.js andÂ TypeScript.

  • React Native 0.79 â€“ Faster, faster,Â faster.

  • Bun 1.2.9, Tailwind CSS 4.1, CKEditor5 45, Zod 4 Beta

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Comparing Tauri and Electron for Building Desktop Apps â€” Electron is a natural choice for building JS and HTML-powered cross-platform desktop apps but numerous alternatives have appeared like Neutralinojs and the Rust-based Tauri. This post does a good job of quickly showing how Tauri differs and why you might chooseÂ it.

Costa Alexoglou

Mastering Default Values with Nullish Coalescing (??) â€” Mattâ€™s a big fan of the ?? operator over the || approach, largely due to JavaScriptâ€™s ideas of what it considers â€˜falsyâ€™.

Matt Smith

How Clerk Integrates with a Next.js Application Using Supabase â€” Learn how Supabase + Clerk work with Next.js to increase security and reduce developmentÂ hours.

Clerk sponsor

Accelerating Large-Scale Test Migration with LLMs â€” How Airbnb completed its first large-scale, LLM-driven code migration in moving from Enzyme to React TestingÂ Library.

Charles Covey-Brandt (Airbnb)

React Reconciliation: The Hidden Engine Behind Your Components â€” React uses a reconciliation algorithm to update the DOM based on changes to the virtual DOM. Understanding how it works is essential for producing fasterÂ apps.

Christian Ekrem

Hiding Elements That Require JavaScript Without UsingÂ JavaScript â€” If youâ€™ve got non-essential features that require JavaScript and you want to hide them for users who have JavaScript disabled for whatever reason, this is a tidy old-school way to doÂ it.

Dade

ğŸ“„ Debugging JavaScript Memory Leaks in Bun Jarred Sumner

ğŸ“„ Using Chrome's (Preview) Prompt API for Data Summarization Raymond Camden

ğŸ“„ How to Easily Reproduce a Flaky Test in Playwright Nicolas Charpentier

ğŸ“„ Securing a Vue App with OpenID Connect and the BFF Pattern â€“ Thatâ€™s Backend-for-Frontend, not Best FriendsÂ Forever. Khalid Abuhakmeh

ğŸ“„ The Case for Web Components with Lit Philipp Kunz

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Next.js 15.3: Now Including Turbopack Builds â€” The popular React framework now includes alpha support for using Turbopack for much faster production builds (especially if you have lots of cores available), community support for Rspack, and new navigationÂ hooks.

The Vercel / Next.js Team

Chrono 2.8: A Natural Language Date Parser â€” Give it a string like â€œtodayâ€, â€œlast Fridayâ€, â€œ2 weeks from nowâ€, or even an entire date and time, and itâ€™ll come up with a date object toÂ suit.

Wanasit Tanakitrungruang

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is the Future â€” 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints and console.log, supports Vitest, Jest, Karma, Jasmine, andÂ more.

Wallaby Team sponsor

ğŸµÂ Communicate with Ableton Live via WebSockets â€” Ableton Live is a popular DAW (digital audio workstation) and this opens up a way to control it fromÂ JavaScript.

Ricardo Matias

  • ğŸ•’ Spacetime 7.9 â€“ Lightweight timezoneÂ library. Now supporting formatting times in SQL ISOÂ format.

  • ğŸ“Š Perspective 3.5 â€“ Streaming data viz and analytics component. The core is written in C++ and compiled toÂ WASM.

  • Embla Carousel 8.6 â€“ Lightweight carousel library with fluid motion and swipeÂ precision.

  • simpleParallax.js 6.1 â€“ Add parallax effects to anyÂ image.

  • Tesseract.js 6.0.1 â€“ Pure JS OCR for 100+ languages.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by Dropbox, Lattice, Bilt Rewards,Â etc.

Working on the frontend? ğŸš€ Frontend Focus is a weekly update â€” trusted by 75,000+ devs â€” covering the essential trends, tools and tips that matter.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere

A quick roundup of other interesting updates and useful resources from across the broader developerÂ landscape:

  • Git has turned 20 years old and GitHub's Taylor Blau caught up with Linus Torvalds to discuss the milestone and the background to the project.

  • Tired of hearing about TypeScript? Why not experiment with programming in PostScript and running games on your printer?

  • Minimal CSS-only Blurry Image Placeholders is an article showing off a very clever technique for using CSS to dynamically create blurry image placeholders prior to an image loadingÂ in.

  • Mozilla's Simon Pieters tells us that default styles for H1 elements are changing and browsers are starting to roll out changes in default styles for nested sectionÂ headings.

  • Docker has released a new extension for VS Code in a collaboration with the Microsoft Container ToolsÂ team.

ã€‘

Costa Alexoglou

Charles Covey-Brandtï¼ˆAirbnbï¼‰

- Reactä½¿ç”¨å¯¹å¸ç®—æ³•æ ¹æ®è™šæ‹ŸDOMçš„æ›´æ”¹æ¥æ›´æ–°DOMã€‚äº†è§£å…¶å·¥ä½œåŸç†å¯¹äºç”Ÿäº§æ›´å¿«çš„åº”ç”¨ç¨‹åºè‡³å…³é‡è¦ã€‚

Christian Ekrem

éœ€è¦ä½¿ç”¨JavaScript ä¸éœ€è¦JavaScript çš„éšè—å…ƒç´  - å¦‚æœæ‚¨æœ‰éœ€è¦JavaScriptçš„ä¸å¿…è¦çš„åŠŸèƒ½ï¼Œå¹¶ä¸”æ‚¨æƒ³å°†å®ƒä»¬éšè—èµ·æ¥ï¼Œä»¥ä½¿ä»–ä»¬å¯¹javaScriptè¿›è¡ŒjavaScriptçš„ç”¨æˆ·éšè—ï¼Œä»»ä½•åŸå› æ˜¯å‡ºäºä»»ä½•åŸå› ï¼Œè¿™æ˜¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ˜“äºæ—§çš„æ—§å¼çš„æ—§é“è·¯ã€‚

dade

ğŸ“„ğŸ“„ğŸ“„ğŸ“„ Khalid Abuhakmeh

ğŸ“„

ğŸ“¢Â åœ¨å…¶ä»–åœ°æ–¹

ä»æ›´å¹¿æ³›çš„å¼€å‘äººå‘˜æ™¯è§‚ä¸­çš„å…¶ä»–æœ‰è¶£çš„æ›´æ–°å’Œæœ‰ç”¨çš„èµ„æºè¿›è¡Œå¿«é€Ÿç»¼è¿°ï¼š

  • gitå·²20å²ï¼Œ

item.title: ã€The tale of a bizarre bug encountered in Google Docsã€‘Googleæ–‡æ¡£ä¸­é‡åˆ°çš„ä¸€ä¸ªå¥‡å¼‚é”™è¯¯çš„æ•…äº‹
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹729 â€” March 28, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

â­Â The State of Vue.js Report 2025 â€” Created with the support of the Vue and Nuxt teams, this is no mere collection of statistics and charts (though thereâ€™s plenty of both) but a thorough update on the state of both projects and an interview with Evan You on Vue (and Vite's) latest developments. Essential reading for any Vue, Vite, or Nuxt user and a one-stop shop for understanding Vue and Nuxt as they stand rightÂ now.

Monterail

Master Chrome's DevTools â€” Join Jon Kuperman for this video course diving into Chrome's DevTools. You'll go beyond console.log(), learning how to inspect, debug, and audit your web apps â€” tracking performance, identifying bottlenecks, making performance gains, and more. Level up your DevToolsÂ skills.

Frontend Masters sponsor

War Story: The Hardest Bug I Ever Debugged â€” A former engineer on the Google Docs team tells the tale of a bizarre error that afflicted Google Docs out of the blue about ten years ago. Itâ€™s a gnarly one and was only solved due to his swift access to V8â€™s engineers. If youâ€™ve ever spent hours digging into a bug, youâ€™ll feel glad you werenâ€™t dealing with thisÂ one!

Jacob Voytko

Next.js's Recent Middleware Security Woes â€” Last weekend, a new version of Next.js landed to resolve a security vulnerability that could allow middleware to be bypassed. Self-hosted Next.js deployments need to be upgraded immediately. The news led to many responses including deep dives into the vulnerability and criticism of how it was allÂ handled.

Lee Robinson (Vercel)

IN BRIEF:

  • Cloudflare has done some work to bring the URLPattern URL matching API to Node.js and Cloudflare Workers.

  • ğŸ¤– If you haven't checked out Google's Gemini AI tool recently (or ever), it now supports generating HTML, JavaScript, and React code in a 'canvas' mode for building components on theÂ fly.

  • ğŸ¤– MCP Node.js Debugger is an attempt to make Node's debugger more accessible to third-party AI coding tools (such as Cursor or Claude Code).

  • ğŸ“Š Is Vite faster than Turbopack? "Well, it depends."

RELEASES:

  • Bun v1.2.7 â€“ Bun's HTTP server now has built-in support for reading and writing cookies using a Map-likeÂ API.

  • Node v18.20.8 (LTS) â€“ Note that Node 18 reaches 'end-of-life' nextÂ month.

  • Sinon 20.0 â€“ Test spies, stubs and mocksÂ library.

  • pnpm 10.7, Babel 7.27.0, ESLint 9.23.0, Neutralinojs 6.0, Material UI v7

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

Writing a Tiny Undo/Redo Stack in JavaScript â€” You might prefer to lean upon an established approach (using Immer patches perhaps), but if you want to implement something small yourself, this mightÂ help.

Julik Tarkhanov

Land Ahoy: Leaving the Sea of Nodes â€” A deeply technical post from a core member of the V8 JavaScript engine team that explains the limitations of Turbofan, one of V8â€™s optimizing compilers. If you donâ€™t care for the internals of how your JavaScript is compiled and run, just be assured the V8 team is working to make it run evenÂ faster.

Darius Mercadier (V8)

Which AI Model Is Best for Fixing Unit Test Errors? Claude, O3-Mini, GPT-4o? â€” Better context wins every time. Wallaby provides AI with test coverage and runtime values to debug smarter. MCP support comingÂ soon.

Wallaby Team sponsor

Mission jQuery Zero: How FreeAgent Removed jQuery From Its App â€” Despite popular developer sentiment, jQueryâ€™s prevalence on the Web continues to be significant but â€œsometimes legends need toÂ retireâ€.

Colin Gemmell

â–¶Â Â React Query API Design: Lessons Learned â€” You might know Dominik for all his work on React Query, TanStack Router, and his epic React Query - The Bad Parts series. Here, he walks us through the design choices made while building React Query and shares lessons and mistakes valuable to anyone building their own libraries. (30Â minutes.)

Dominik Dorfmeister (TkDodo)

Deploying a Next.js App to Production on Any Server â€” A popular article from last year thatâ€™s been updated for 2025 and Next.jsÂ 15.

Kamrannetic

ğŸ”’ Protect Against AI Bots, Fraud, and Abuse in Real Time â€” WorkOS Radar protects your app with advanced device fingerprinting â€” stop fake signups, free tier abuse, bot attacks and brute force attemptsÂ today.

WorkOS sponsor

ğŸ“„ Expressing Japanese Grammar in the TypeScript Type System â€“ A curious project out of leftÂ field. Yifeng Wang

ğŸ“„ Directives: A Core Feature of the Angular Toolkit Vyacheslav Borodin

ğŸ“„ You Should Know This Before Choosing Next.js Eduardo BouÃ§as

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Babylon.js 8.0: Microsoft's JavaScript 3D Engine â€” 8.0 adds support for improved â€˜image based lightingâ€™ and â€˜area lightsâ€™ for environmental lighting and shadows, extra control of the render pipeline, and a new lightweight viewer. And, as always, they have â–¶ï¸Â a short video showing it allÂ off.

Microsoft

ğŸ¤–Â An MCP Server for Playwright and Browser Automation â€” MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers enable certain LLM-based agents (such as Claude, Claude Code, and Cursor) to perform actions on a system outside of their usual sandbox. This new project from Microsoft enables such LLMs to interact with browsers viaÂ Playwright.

Microsoft

Lexical 0.29: An Easy-to-Extend Text Editor Framework from Meta â€” A text editor framework built by Meta with extensibility, accessibility, and cross platform support in mind (thereâ€™s even a Swift variant for iOS). Thereâ€™s a live playground if you want to give it aÂ try.

Meta / Facebook

ğŸ”Â Fuzzball: Fuzzy String Matching Library â€” To tackle those cases where whatâ€™s typed isnâ€™t quite whatâ€™s wanted. Thereâ€™s a neat tree-themed Web-basedÂ demo.

Nolan

  • Axios 0.30 â€“ Long-standing, promise-based isomorphic HTTPÂ client.

  • Solito 4.4 â€“ React Native +Â Next.js. Now supporting Next.jsÂ 15.

  • InversifyJS 7.2 â€“ Inversion of control container forÂ JavaScript.

  • jscodeshift 17.3 â€“ JavaScript codemod toolkit fromÂ Facebook.

  • Verdaccio 6.1 â€“ Lightweight Node.js private proxyÂ registry.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by 1000s of orgs, including Dropbox, Lattice, Bilt Rewards and manyÂ more.

ğŸ“Š Jspreadsheet â€“ Lightweight JS data grid with Excel-like controls. Create rich web spreadsheets fast. Try itÂ now.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere

A quick roundup of other interesting updates and useful resources from across the broader developerÂ landscape:

  • <select> elements have always been notoriously tricky to style with CSS but there's a new standardized approach beginning to become available.

  • ls-lint is a mature tool for linting file and directoryÂ names.

  • Someone's managed to get Go code to compile and run on the PlayStationÂ 2.

  • ğŸ‘‘ People's experiments with TypeScript's type system continue with the latest creation being a chess engine built from TypeScript types.

  • LLM wrangler Simon Willison was getting annoyed at being unable to easily visualize incomplete JSON documents so he built an 'incomplete JSON' prettyÂ printer.

item.title: ã€The Rsdoctor will see you nowã€‘RSDOCTORç°åœ¨ä¼šè§æ‚¨
item.description:
ã€

#â€‹728 â€” March 21, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Rsdoctor 1.0: An Analyzer for Rspack and Webpack â€” A one-stop, intelligent build analyzer making it easier to identify bottlenecks and optimize performance. Itâ€™s part of the same family of tools as Rspack (a Rust-powered web bundler) but is fully webpack compatible. If youâ€™ve ever asked why your build times are too long, this is forÂ you.

ByteDance Inc.

ğŸ’¡ In other Rust-powered JavaScript tooling news, the Oxlint JavaScript linter is now in beta. Imagine ESLint, but it runs in seconds on large codebases (indeed, it can process Microsoft's VS Code repo in under aÂ second).

Add Excel-like Spreadsheet Functionality to Your JavaScript Apps â€” SpreadJS is the industry-leading JavaScript spreadsheet for adding advanced spreadsheet features to your enterprise apps. Build finance, analysis, budget, and other apps. Excel I/O, 500+ calc functions, tables, charts, and more. View demosÂ now.

SpreadJS from MESCIUS inc sponsor

ğŸ“‰Â How We Made Our Rich Text Editor Load Faster â€” CKEditor is a long-standing, full featured GPL and commercially licensed rich text editor but its complexity can come with a performance cost. In this two part series (part two here), the CKEditor team digs into how theyâ€™ve recently significantly boosted itsÂ performance.

Szymon Cofalik (CKEditor)

Next.js vs TanStack â€” An incisive essay from a developer whoâ€™s had enough of the Next.js approach and has found solace in the approach offered by the increasingly capable TanStack collection of tools (as well asÂ Vite).

Kyle Gill

IN BRIEF:

  • This automatically updated runtime compatibility table lets you see how/if different server-side JavaScript runtimes support differentÂ APIs.

  • ğŸ’¬ If you'd like to hang out on Discord and chat with other Node.js developers, there's now an official Node.js Discord server.

  • The Node.js TSC has voted to stop distributing Corepack with future versions of Node. Corepack was originally introduced as a way to manage other package managers.

  • ğŸ› ï¸ Make Bookmarklets is a handy tool for turning JavaScript into bookmarklet code that you can use directly in a browserÂ bookmark.

RELEASES:

  • Parcel v2.14.0 â€“ The zero-config bundler adds a new CLI to scaffold apps, first-class MDX support, and beta support for React Server Components.

  • Ionic 8.5 â€“ Cross-platform JS app developmentÂ platform.

  • ğŸ“Š Billboard.js 3.15.0 â€“ D3-powered JS chart library.

  • React Router 7.4

ğŸ“’Â Articles & Tutorials

How to Build a Snake AI Game with Docker and TensorFlow.js â€” Youâ€™ve probably heard about people â€˜vibe codingâ€™ games by letting LLMs do the coding work, but what if you want to build a game yourself that has neural network powered elements? TensorFlow.js offers oneÂ solution that you could just as easily adapt to non-gamingÂ contexts.

Manvar and Raina (Docker)

The Great ESLint v9 Migration Adventure: A Developer's SurvivalÂ Guide â€” â€œLetâ€™s just sayâ€¦ Iâ€™ve seen things. I hit all the bumps, took all the wrong turns, and somehow made it to the other sideâ€”so you donâ€™t haveÂ to.â€

Yacine Kharoubi

ğŸ”’ Protect Against AI Bots, Fraud, and Abuse in Real Time â€” WorkOS Radar protects your app with advanced device fingerprinting â€” stop fake signups, free tier abuse, bot attacks and brute force attemptsÂ today.

WorkOS sponsor

React Trends in 2025 â€” Each year Robin does a post giving his opinion on what trends he sees arising over the next year. Last year, he put his money on Astro, RSCs, Vercel, and Biome â€“ this year he points at React Server Components, shadcn/ui, TanStack Start, React Router, andÂ more.

Robin Wieruch

Build a Custom RAG AI Agent with TypeScript and Jupyter â€” Deno, Ollama, and a few different AI models come together in this tutorial for storing document embeddings in a vector store and querying them for use in a basicÂ agent.

Kitson Kelly

ğŸ“„ Training AI to Uncover Malicious JavaScript Intent and Make the Web Safer Cejuela and Zheng (Cloudflare)

ğŸ“„ Lazy Load Background Images with the IntersectionObserver API Anna Monus

ğŸ“„ Web Components vs. Framework Components:Â Whatâ€™s the Difference? Gabriel Shoyombo

ğŸ“„ Detecting Browser Zoom Changes in JavaScript Kirupa Chinnathambi

ğŸ“„ Making a Browser Based Game With Vanilla JS and CSS Eoin McGrath

ğŸ“„ Deno Shows Us There's a Better Way Mac Chaffee

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Introducing Motion for Vue â€” Motion is a popular and powerful animation library most commonly associated with React, but now thereâ€™s a new Vue flavor and itâ€™s feature complete, too.

Matt Perry (Motion)

Reveal.js 5.2: The HTML Presentation Framework â€” Brings elegant presentations to anyone with a Web browser. v5.2 adds the ability to trigger â€˜lightboxesâ€™ where viewers can see images and videos in a way where they stand outÂ more.

Hakim El Hattab

Introducing @clerk/agent-toolkit â€” Build agentic systems with support for user and organizational management. Compatible with Vercel's AI SDK andÂ LangChain.

Clerk sponsor

Konva: A JavaScript 2D Canvas Library â€” The native API for Canvas elements is pretty good, but Konva is a popular abstraction that sits on top and provides a more structured way to work with shapes, styling, events, animations, and more (lots of demos with code). It also has extra integration libraries for Vue, Svelte and React.

Konva

Typist 8.0: Tiptap-Based Rich Text Editor Component â€” Simple and opinionated. You can try several examples linked in the sidebar. Well suited for basic rich text situations like writing comments or messages and has a single-line mode. GitHubÂ repo.

Doist

PeanoScript: TypeScript But It's a Theorem Prover â€” An experimental proof assistant for Peano arithmetic based on TypeScriptÂ syntax.

mjgrzymek

  • Gridstack.js 11.5 â€“ Build responsive interactive dashboardsÂ quickly.

  • Repomix 0.3 â€“ Pack an entire repository into a single, AI-friendlyÂ file.

  • DOCX 9.3 â€“ Generate .docx / WordÂ files fromÂ JavaScript.

  • ğŸ–¼ï¸ Parvus 3.0 â€“ Dependency-free image lightboxÂ control.

  • BlockNote 0.26 â€“ 'Notion-style' block-basedÂ editor.

  • ğŸ¤– wllama 2.3 â€“ WebAssembly binding forÂ llama.cpp.

  • Pixi.js 8.9 â€“ Fast, flexible 2D WebGLÂ renderer.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ¹ STRICH: Add blazing fast and reliable 1D/2D Barcode Scanning to your web apps. Free demo app and 30-day trialÂ available.

Meticulous automatically creates and maintains an E2E UI test suite with zero developer effort. Relied on by 1000s of orgs, including Dropbox, Lattice, Bilt Rewards and manyÂ more.

ğŸ“Š Jspreadsheet â€“ Lightweight JS data grid with Excel-like controls. Create rich web spreadsheets fast. Try itÂ now.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere

A quick roundup of other interesting updates and useful resources from across the broader developerÂ landscape:

  • John Tuckner took a look at the murky world of buying browser extensions for 'fun and profit.'

  • If you're using VS Code and GitHub Copilot, did you know you can ask Copilot about VS Code's own features?

  • Ever wondered what's involved in building a container image from scratch?

  • A look at building a Lisp interpreter in 66 lines of JavaScript.

  • "As an engineer, Iâ€™d rather be called stupid than stay silent."
